BC sat her down, kholo to kholo, and told her how impressive she is and how much her actions honor her clan.

And then she added one last warning.

"Anchor Root is Bonecrusher's friend. And nobody speaks that way about her friend Anchor Root and lives. Not even Anchor Root." 2/2

In SoT, my gnoll ranger, Bonecrusher, is a rain-scribe, so to-date I've always studied with Anchor Root. Last session, she commented that she didn't know why BC always chooses to study with her, and made several self-disparaging remarks. 1/

She touched each of them with care before her fingers came to rest on the last, which had been carved into the likeness of an antelope. She slowly placed it upon her face with reverence and resolve. Her quarry was near, and today was not a day for peace or healing. 4/4

Recently she has been helping to track a villain who has been targeting the Magaambya, and as her hunt led her closer she discovered a grim warning—a haunting display of masks and robes belonging to several others who had gone missing. 3/

She saw it as a sign, buried the antelope skull in the desert, and journeyed on foot to plead her case to the Magaambya. After gaining admission, she studied hard in search of magic that could heal her home and carved a mask that represented her new path: a horned scarab. 2/

Anyway, I just wanted that footnote to exist somewhere outside my brain. If you want to refer to the creature in Osiriani, feel free to say something along the lines of 'neheb deshret.'

And I just found it extremely compelling that the creature's original name may have held several different meanings and connotations, alternatively vilifying or pitying it, as the language evolved over 3,000 years of Golarion history. 3/

This line came about because Ancient Osiriani is written in hieroglyphics and is roughly analogous to Ancient Egyptian.

In Ancient Egyptian, "nhb" means to harm, be violent, roar, or howl, while "nHb" (spoken further back in the throat) can mean to harness or to yoke. 2/

I'd like to talk briefly about a line I wrote in Monsters of Myth in reference to Desert's Howl:

"...this name, originally in Osirion, is possibly a corruption of “the desert’s harm” or “beneath the desert’s yoke.” 1/

The half-orc crossed the cavern to retrieve his companion's blade, snapped it in half, and threw it at his feet.

When we return, the party is excited. They have an idea. They all start grappling knights in groups of 1-2 and jumping from the tower. The knights are forced to cast Featherfall, and my players keep them grappled and RIDE THEM DOWN TO THE BOTTOM.

I give them one action to try and do something. The party is panicked. The rogue could maybe free themself, the paladin could probably charm a single target, but they've got nothing. It's a good time to take a 15 minute break.

The players try to infiltrate Feathergale Spire, and are caught and subdued. They're stripped of their gear, put in chains, and taken to the top of the tower to be interrogated by the commander. Afterwards, he waves his hand and his knights go to push everyone off the tower.

So I was running a modified version of PotA, and the players were just starting to explore the valley and tangling a bit with the Feathergale Knights (aerial knights on giant vultures). Of course they target the mounts, but surprise(!), all of the knights can cast Featherfall.

They do get baseline xp just for playing/adventuring, because I want them to feel like they're always progressing and that these things are more like boons or bonuses, but I want them to choose the style of gameplay they enjoy. That's loosely the process that I follow, anyway.

There are also emergent goals. They discovered a ruined town in the desert and decided that they wanted to restore it, attract new townsfolk, and run it on the side as a settlement. Now, as they grow their town and expand its influence, that also grants xp.

But they each also have individual goals. Eldritch Knight wants to lead a powerful clan, so the party gains secondary xp for forming alliances. Scout wants revenge on an influential NPC, so there's a considerable xp bounty on that particular individual.

For example, my current group's explicit purpose for adventuring is to re-discover lost histories and forgotten magics. So I award them all primary xp based on the lore that they uncover, and for formulating theories or experiments based on it.

RE: How do I award milestone xp?

I award the most milestone xp for characters progressing towards the goals that they've defined for themselves, and I award it to the entire party because, hey, you gotta uplift each other, right?

You're all making great points! It makes sense now that I think about it, but the comments point to it depending on how much combat is involved. I've gone from 6, to 4, and now 3, and now I think that's really just in line with playstyle changes in the TTRPG community as a whole.

@PhDGoblin @DnDDetector My players don't know this, but I have some close friends that I absolutely give recaps to right afterwards and geek out about the game with. I also tell them what I'm planning a few months ahead of time, so they get a little bit of the DM experience themselves in a way.

But to the heart of the original tweet, he was always incredibly supportive of all of us discovering and becoming ourselves. To this day he occasionally comes to my events and enjoys embarrassing me by gushing about what I'm doing. I'm really thankful for him.

When he ran ttrpg's they were almost always ones that he designed. All of his systems were % based—I think Palladium was a big inspiration—but most notably all of them allowed players to create their own spells, magic items, tech devices, etc., and that made things interesting.

At this point would you be surprised to learn he's a sword fighter? Well, he's also a belly dancer. And back in his day he was known for being able to recline his torso back horizontally from a fighting stance and weave side-to-side like a snake. He often did so reflexively.

Most of his life he was a leatherworker. He loves camping and once in the middle of a trip he decided he needed new shoes, pulled out tools and scrap leather, and made himself a pair of moccasins that same day. He's super crafty in general and we used to do weekend projects.

Dad is an OG sci-fi geek. When I was growing up and he would reference something before my time—usually old books or movies—after realizing I didn't understand he would tell me his own version of it like it was a story. I've been let down before when his version was way better.

This is by far the most likes I've ever gotten on one tweet. Lol. Do you all want to know more about my Dad? He's pretty amazing tbh. He was my hero growing up and I love him a lot. https://t.co/Fp1fyiJxqG

I don't allow torture scenes on camera, but, even from a mechanical perspective, if a puzzle can always be solved with a known solution then why does it exist? Your players deserve to tell better stories, and you can help them do that.

I tell my players straight away that torture will never produce reliable information in my games. To do that they need to determine the NPC's needs and address those. Are they starving? Feed them. Are they afraid of someone? Convince them that you can protect them.
